Comments_List: material properties, and how to decide the material type based on application
I learned The reactions of the human body and application/clinical relevance of materials.
I learned a lot of knowledge about material science and biology.

I enjoyed the material but I think that the lecture notes could be better organized. It was hard to understand what was written on the board sometimes. The lecture powerpoints were a little more clear. I think that slides with summary points at the end would be helpful.

I thought the blog posts were an interesting way to connect what we learned in class to real world applications and to read about current research.

Strength: application orientated, introduce more biomedical application.

weakness: know some of the physiology knowledge before taking this course can have a better understanding.

The course is designed well in terms of the type of content and frequency of assignments. I do Wish the graduate version had more advanced material science and that in general the class had fewer or less frequent exams.
I thought this was a good BME elective to take. It was interesting and the Professor was very nice and engaging.
I will recommend to students who would like to do research in the biomedical field. For others, it's hard to take the test if don't know the human biology.
Yup I would As it is a great intro course
Professor is really nice. And you can learn some fundamental knowledge about material science. It is a good introductory level class.
